summary.seg: This mid 15th-century manuscript contains an important collection of Middle English religious prose and verse. It features a commentary on the Seven Penitential Psalms, known as The Seven Psalms, and meditations on the Passion, known as the Meditations upon the Seven Days of the Week, which were both translated out of French into English by Eleanor [née Malet] Hull (c. 1394–1460), the daughter of Sir John Malet of Enmore, Somerset (d. before 1395), retainer of John of Gaunt, duke of Lancaster, and of his wife, Joan (c.1370–1426). Eleanor Hull is the first woman translator from French into English who is known by name. The copy of The Seven Psalms preserved in this manuscript is unique, and only one other extant copy of the Meditations is known (Chicago, University of Illinois, MS 80). It is only in this manuscript, however, that Eleanor is credited for her work: she is identified as the translator in rubrics at the end of each work (ff. 147r, 179v) and in another inscription by a different hand ('Alinor Hull', f. 148r).

Eleanor is thought to have made her translations in the 1420s, following the death of her husband, Sir John Hull, and while residing at Sopwell Priory, a Benedictine nunnery in Hertfordshire that was dependent on the Benedictine abbey of St Albans. Eleanor was associated with the latter house for a large part of her life: in February 1417, she was admitted to St Albans' confraternity, earning her a place in the so-called St Albans Benefactors' Book (now London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero D VII) as 'Domina Elianora de Hulle'. Moreover, in 1456, together with the priest Roger Huswyf, she donated a four-volume copy of the Postillae of Nicholas of Lyra to the abbey, now Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.7.7-10.

Eleanor's connection with St Albans likely explains how her works came to Richard Fox (d. 1454), proctor or steward of St Albans. Fox copied a large section of MS Kk.1.6 (ff. 1r [table of contents], 194r-214v), perhaps in collaboration with the five other scribes who copied the manuscript's original contents. He also rubricated the entire volume after its completion and was responsible for writing out the rubrics that mention Eleanor by name (ff. 147r, 179v). Fox was the manuscript's first owner, as can be evidenced from his will of 1454, in which it is identifiable by its incipit as one of the 'vi bounde bokes' that he passed on to his son John.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: Quires formed of paper folded in quarto, with outer and inner bifolia formed of parchment.

foliation.p: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf.

note.p: A hand from the second half of the 16th century or first half of the 17th century has written names from the Gesta Romanorum in margins throughout ff. 216r-242r.
Table of contents add by an unidentified 18th-century hand to the former front pastedown (preserved in part on the inside upper cover).

Annotations in English added to empty margins and spaces by one or more 16th-century or early 17th-century hands:
'prope ardor procull ardorum [...]' (f. 52r, outer margin).
'Noverint [? universi] [...]' (f. 70v, upper margin).
Illegible (f. 74r, outer margin).
'for vs god made all thinge better the we could deuise / and yet in our vses we do him disspise' (f. 89r, outer margin).
'Let vs honor praise And gloryfy his name / And distribute to him his due honor and fame / Anno Domini 1571' (f. 97r, outer margin).
'P[?ar] my humfre owen de suffolke amen / Selled and delyvered in the presens of master thomas hoopton' (f. 100r, upper margin).
Beginning: 'God made man to his owen lykenes, to the intent we should do good and not evill for yf we remember our selfes we are bound, and rebounde, to geve to him our maker [etc]' (f. 102r, outer margin).
'Item payed to [...]' (f. 128r, upper margin).
Item payd to master harve of darsam / Item the county of Suffolke knave Amen' (f. 131v, upper margin).
'I trvst he will vs to him call, and save vs from a bitter fall' (f. 147r, outer margin).
'The trentall of Saynte Gregorie the bishope' (f. 215v).
'My loue did watche me and when se did cacthe [sic] me then did she scrache me' [2x] (f. 215v).
'Whill the grasse grouethe oft, the horse may starve / Trust in faire promises, oft times may swarve' (f. 215v).
'Afflictus sum et humilatus sum nimis' (f. 242v, gap between text).
'Suffolk and Norffolk / amen dico vobis' (f. 245r, outer margin).
'To the ryght worshipfull / to his veary loving frind' (f. 247r, outer margin).
Collation formula by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L. (inside lower cover).

binding.p: Binding by Gray of Cambridge, dated 1941 by a note on the front pastedown. Millboard three-quarter binding with marbled cloth covering and brown leather spine. The title and classmark are tooled in gold on the spine (title and classmark from previous binding pasted on the front pastedown).
Binding height: 282 mm, width: 210 mm, depth: 65 mm.

provenance.p: The name of Arthur Hopton Hopton, Arthur is inscribed in the upper margin of f. 242v ('Arturus Hopton'): he was a member of the Hopton family of Westwood in Blythburgh in North-East Suffolk, as a 16th-century or early 17th-century note suggests: 'P[our] my humfre owen de suffolke amen / Selled and delyvered in the presens of master thomas hoopton' (f. 100v, upper margin). The same hand has written a note with the date 'Anno Domini 1571' (f. 97r, outer margin); a note on a payment to master Harvey of Darsham in Suffolk: 'Item payd to master harve of darsam / Item the county of Suffolke knave Amen' (f. 131v, upper margin); and 'Suffolk and Norffolk / amen dico vobis' (f. 245r, outer margin). Darsham is situated a few miles to the south-east of Blythburgh. If these notes were written by Arthur Hopton (which is unclear because he writes his name in a different stylised script), then he almost certainly was Arthur Hopton (c. 1540-1607), High Sheriff of Suffolk.

The name of Arthur Melle Melle, Arthur: 'Arthur melle ded wryt thys' (f. 2r, lower margin). Perhaps Arthur Melle, son of Henry Melle and his wife Frances, born in 1548 at Bramfield, five miles south-west from Blythburgh.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University Library in July 1664: no. 4 in the inventory of Holdsworth's manuscripts compiled by William Crowe (Dd.8.45, f. 148r).

Inscribed on the inside cover is '455', which is the number given to the manuscript in a handlist compiled c. 1672 and now MS Oo.7.59, which continued the sequence of numbers used by Thomas James in the Ecloga of 1600.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.1.6, ff. 1-245

msItem.title: Table of contents (fragment)
msItem.explicit: 1r: How seynt gregory saued his moderes sowle by his preyere thus endeth the contentus of this booke quod rychard ffox
msItem.finalRubric: 1v: Thus endeth the Contentes of this Book: Quod Rychard ffox
msItem.note: Due to the loss of a preceding folio (or folios), only the final item in the table of contents survives, referring to the Trental of Saint Gregory on ff. 242r-245v.

msItem.title: Prophecies for the years 1552 and 1553
msItem.incipit: 1r: In the yer of ower lord Anno thowsand vC lij and one schalt theyr be doyng and done
msItem.explicit: 1v: for after thys to your [...] shall no hurte ffalle
msItem.finalRubric: 1v: Anno Regny Marie Regene Anglie primi primo xix daye Julij

msItem.author: Eleanor Hull
msItem.title: The Seven Psalms
msItem.incipit: 2r: Ihesu cryst most mercyful haue mercy on me sinful and helpe me as hyt is nedful
msItem.explicit: 147r: Venite benedicti patris mei percipite regnum quod vobis para cum est ab origine mundi quod nobis et illis prestare dignenetur qui cum patre et spiritu sancto vivit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 147rv: Here endeth the .vij. Psalmes the wheche . dame Alyanore Hull Transelated out of ffrensche in to Englesche
msItem.note: Unique copy, beginning with a verse prayer to Christ; the name 'Richard ffox' written at the foot of f. 50r.

msItem.author: Eleanor Hull
msItem.title: Meditations upon the Seven Days of the Week
msItem.incipit: 2r: Thes orysons and thes meditacions þat folowen here ben in party takyn of seynt austyn party of seynt ancelm party of seynt barnard and party of oþer wrytynges for to enflawme the hert and the corage of hem þat redyn it in the love of god and for to make a man to know hymself thei be not to be red in noyse but in quyete
msItem.explicit: 179v: the ioy of hymsylfe that ys all þe parfyt joy of heuyn ynto that most parfyt joy he bryng us all amen so be it amen
msItem.finalRubric: 179v: Explicit deo gracias Here ende the meditacyons upon the vij. dayes of the woke veni domine Jhesu Nomen scriptoris walterus plenus Amoris / Alyanore Hull drow out of ffrensche alle this before wreten in this lytylle Booke
msItem.note: Another copy survives in Chicago, University of Illinois, MS 80.

msItem.title: The Twenty-One Passions of Our Lord
msItem.incipit: 180r: Our lord aperyd to an holy man and seyd hym ho þat louyth me record and haue ofte mynd of my passyon and he þat sekyth me on þe crosse he schal fynd me fac nos tuam bone iesu passyonem mortem et crucem digne uenarari ad lorare laudare et glorificare
msItem.explicit: 192r: now blessed be ȝe wiþ your sone that ys and schall be wiþ god the fader and the haly gost o parfyt god per omnia secula secularum amen deo gracias

msItem.title: Collection of four medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 193r: For a hete in the stomake: Take sokore lange debeffe whyt endyffe sorell boraghe sowthystell vyolet leuis daundelyon off eche a handffull and seth them
msItem.explicit: 193r: Take cheruyle and clarye and stampe them smale and lay yt uppon a clothe as brode as youre hande and as thyke and caste therin ryse flowere very thyme and lay yt to th raynes of the backe

msItem.title: Collection of four medical recipes, two for horses, and two possibly for humans, directed at colic and gout
msItem.incipit: 193r: A medson for the glandres take frankkingsens wiþ a rope of barlek than garlek he[...] ben on and burnett in a chafin dyshe wiþ rotes and holdytt under his n[...]
msItem.explicit: 193r: and may butter boyle them together and p[ut] it upon a playstere and lay it upon the sore

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Meditation on the Passion
msItem.rubric: 194r: Here begynneth an holy meditacion to oure lord criste Jhesus hangyng on the Croose compiled and made by John lidgate late a monke of the house of Seynt Edmundus of Bery on whose sowle God haue mercy. Amen.
msItem.incipit: 194r: Man to reform þyn exile and þy loose / ffro paradyse place of moste plesaunce
msItem.explicit: 196r: No bettur socour ner support in ȝoure neede / Than ofte tymes thyngk on Cristus Passion
msItem.finalRubric: 196r: Here enduth this holy preyere to the lord Criste jhesus hangyng on the Crosse: Veni domine jhesu

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Prayer on the Passion
msItem.rubric: 196v: Another prayer to our lord Hangyng on þe Croosse
msItem.incipit: 194r: Uppon the Croosse nayled y was for the / Suffred deth to pay þy raunsoun
msItem.explicit: 197r: Nowe for þi moderes meeke mediacyoun / At her requeste be to vs merciable

msItem.title: Prayer to Christ
msItem.rubric: 197r: Here endith this preyere to oure lord And begynneth a nother
msItem.incipit: 194r: Almyȝti god maker of Heuene / Erthe and Eyre Watur and Wynde
msItem.explicit: 197r: In heuene þer to haue a place / Wher Jhesu þou haue mercy on me. Amen

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The hymn Vexilla Regis Prodeunt
msItem.rubric: 197v: Here endith þis preyore to our lord Jhesu And begynneth the ymne Vexilla regia prodeunte
msItem.incipit: 198r: Royal Banerys unrolled of the kynge / Towarde his Batayle in Bosra steyned Reede
msItem.explicit: 199r: To þe holy Gooste grace to haue memorie / On his ffyue woundes and his passioun
msItem.note: Here not attributed to John Lydgate, but in MacCracken's edition.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Verses On the Five Joys addressed to the Virgin Mary
msItem.rubric: 199r: Here endith the ymne vexilla regis prodeunt And begyneth an holy preyer to oure moste blesset lady Seynt mari of here .v. joyes. lydgate
msItem.incipit: 198r: Qvene of heuene of Helle eeke Emperesse / Lady of this worlde O verrey loode sterre
msItem.explicit: 200v: On cristus Passion and on here Joyes ffyue / To make ȝow stronge be war for get hem nought

msItem.title: Prayer on the Seven Joys of the Virgin Mary in Heaven
msItem.incipit: 200v: Heyle be glad and joye with outen ende / Modyr of god to whome he doth honoure
msItem.explicit: 201vr: And to þat Ioye þat neuer schall haue ffyne / Os gyde and leede þe ryght redy waye
msItem.note: Attributed to Thomas Hoccleve by MacCracken.

msItem.title: Regina celi letare
msItem.rubric: 202r Here endith a preyere to our lady And begynneth Regina celi letare
msItem.incipit: 202r In whome fyrste þis worlde began / Whan Gabriell grete þe on his knee
msItem.explicit: 203v As ȝe to geder were bounden in fere Regina celi letare

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Prayer to St Edmund
msItem.rubric: 202r: Here endith regina celi And begyneth an holy preyer to seynt Edmund kyng . Martyr and mayden
msItem.incipit: 202r: Glorious Edmunde kyng of Estyngelonde / Calde of martyris Charboncle and Rubie
msItem.explicit: 203v: Aue rex gentis schall eche day be ther songe / Callynge to the for helpe in þer mooste neede

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Song of Virtue
msItem.rubric: 203r: Here enduth þis holy preyere of Seynt Edmunde the whyche D. j. lydgate made And begynneth a songe of vertu of þe seyde John lydgatis makyng
msItem.incipit: 203v: Off hony men gaderen out swetnesse / Of wyne and spisus is made good Ipocrase
msItem.explicit: 205v: Cleyme of his mercy to haue possession / Wyth hym to dwelle aboue þe sterres clere

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Verses against Haste
msItem.rubric: 205v: Here endith the songe on þis worde Who sueth vertu vertu schalt he leere And begyneth the dite on þis worde He hasteth weel that wisely can abide
msItem.incipit: 205v: Alle haste is odious where as discressioun / Off wylfulnesse hath non intresse
msItem.explicit: 208v: Haste in alle perylys to Cristus Passioun / Enbrace þat Baner and do þer by a byde

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Churl and the Bird
msItem.incipit: 208v: Problemus lykenessus and ffygurys / Whiche prued byn ffructuous of sentensse
msItem.explicit: 214v: In other tymes sche hath no ffantesy / Thus euerythynge as Clerkes specyfye
msItem.note: Attributed to John Lydgate in another manuscript.

msItem.title: The Trental of Saint Gregory (Summary)
msItem.rubric: 215v: The Trentall of Syntt Gregoree the Byschope
msItem.incipit: 215v: De Nativitate done three masses
msItem.explicit: 215v: Summa xxx masses
msItem.note: Summary of the text on ff. 242v-245v added in a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of thirty-two tales from the Gesta Romanorum translated from Latin
msItem.incipit: 216r: Inclides in the cite of rome regnyd a fulle wyse man and aboue all þyng he was mercyfull it happyd ones as he walked by a forest he met wiþ a pore man
msItem.explicit: 242v: whan he saw this wiþ shame and confusioun he went away and þe pore man dwellyd þere all his lyf after
msItem.finalRubric: 242v: Here endith a ffewe of the Tales of Gestes Romonorum

msItem.title: The Trental of Saint Gregory
msItem.incipit: 242v: Sum tyme in rome a pope þer was / that hadde a moder fayre of face
msItem.explicit: 245v: fowre aungellys he sey with her goo / In to blysse there god bryng ows to. Amen

support.material: Paper quires with parchment guards at the beginning, middle and end. Paper, folded in quarto.

watermark.seg: Fleur ( 50 50 ) in the margins and divided over two leaves, comparable to Briquet (1907), 6648, 66649-6652, but with a different leaf structure. These examples are dated to 1442-1554 (e.g. see f. 4).
Fleur ( 30 35 ) in the margins and divided over two leaves, comparable to Briquet (1907), 6381, but the watermark is barely visible. These examples are dated to 1376-1390 (e.g. see f. 69).
Cercle ( 30 35 ) in the margins and divided over two leaves, comparable to Briquet (1907), 3126, but the watermark is barely visible. These examples are dated to 1358 (e.g. see f. 73).
Char ( 45 42 ) in the margins and divided over two leaves, comparable to Briquet (1907), 3520, but with only two wheels. These examples are dated to 1450-1453 (e.g. see f. 134).

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises almost entirely quires of ten leaves. It is formed of five codicological units, which bear some evidence of different methods of preparation and production but which appear to have been planned and produced contemporaneously, with the intention that they be bound together from the outset. The sequence of medieval leaf signatures also runs continuously across the entire manuscript. Except for the fourth unit, where leaves are missing and the text ends imperfectly, each section ends with a blank space or page and the excision of the remaining leaves of the final quire, which were themselves probably blank. These units are:
1: Quires 1-15 (ff. 2-147)
2: Quires 16-19 (ff. 148-179)
3: Quires 20-21 (ff. 180-193)
4: Quires 22-24 (ff. 194-215)
5: Quires 25-27 (ff. 216-245) Prior to Quire 1, there is a single ruled leaf surviving (f. 1r), bearing text, and a further blank but similarly ruled stub. It is not clear whether these once formed a quire or were intended as endleaves; the stub bears some evidence on its recto side of having been used as a pastedown. It is not included in the collation, therefore.

list.item: Quire 1510-4 (ff. 142r-147v: 7th-10th leaves missing, with stubs remaining)
Quire 2110-6 (ff. 190r-193v: 4th-7th and 10th leaves missing, with stubs remaining)
Quire 24two (ff. 214r-215v: perhaps also originally a quire of ten leaves, with only the 1st and 10th remaining, all of the rest missing or some missing and others perhaps blank and excised)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures comprising lower case letters and Roman numerals - a-z, et [Tironian note], con [Tironian note], title [symbol], and 'est' - in the lower right-hand corner of the first halves of each quire.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in lower right-hand corner of the last verso of each leaf of each quire.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 29-39 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Scribe A, Richard Fox, copied f. 1r (fragmentary table of contents), and ff. 194r-214v in a script with the overall appearance ofAnglicana (e.g. double-compartment 'a' and hour-glass shaped 'g'), but with a strong Secretary influence: note the regular use of an open 'w' (alongside the Anglicana 'w' that is closed by two bows); the consistent use of 'r' on the baseline, often 2-shaped, and the absence of the Anglicana long-r; and the lack of loops on ascenders. Also note the dominant 8-shaped 's' at the end of words, perhaps a stylized kidney-shaped Secretary 's', with the occasional occurence of Anglicana sigma-shaped 's'.
Scribe B copied ff. 2r-147v in a clear Secretary script, but with regular use of Anglicana 'g', and consistent use of Textualis for Latin quotations.

Scribe C, who identifies himself as 'Walterus plenus Amoris (Walter ? Fullalove) on f. 179v, copied ff. 148r-179v in Secretary script, but with Anglicana forms, including the long 'r', and 'w' closed with two bows.

Scribe D copied ff. 180r-192r almost wholly in an Anglicana script, including double-compartment 'a', round 'e', long 'r', sigma-shaped 's' in final positions, 'w' closed with 2 bows, and loops on ascenders. However, the angle of the script, and the rare appereance of unlooped 'w', betray the influence of Secretary script.

Scribe E copied ff. 216r-242v in a Secretary script (e.g. note the one-compartment 'a' and open 'g'), but with a strong Anglicana influence, as can be witness from the regular use of long 'r', sigma-shaped 's' in final positions, looped 'w' (alongside the Secretary 'w'), and consistently looped ascenders.

Scribe F copied ff. 242v-245v in a script predominantly featuring Anglicana letter forms, featuring the two-compartment 'a', round 'e', hour-glass shaped 'g', long 'r', looped 'w', and looped ascenders. However, the script's angularity and occasional use of single-compartment 'a', indicate the influence of Secretary as well.
Texts added to empty spaces on pages and in margins have been written in Secretary scripts

decoNote.p: One- to nine-line blue initial with red penwork decoration and pen-flourishing throughout, some of which are heavily stained, see ff. 82v, 131r, 148r, and 148v.
One-line plain capitals in blue or red ink.
Small capitals highlighted in red throughout.
Paraphs alternately in blue and red (ff. 2r-147r), and in red (ff. 148r-179v), but with occasional blue ones on ff. 160v, 176v, 176v, 177v
Underlining and corrections in red ink.
Cadels with human and zoomorphic faces on ff. 171r, 172v, 174r.
Introductory and final rubrics, and Latin quotations rubricated in red ink.

note.p: A hand from the mid-15th centuyr or second half of the 15th century has inscribed 'Christi' at the top of f. 2r, 'Alinor Hulle' at the top of 148r, and 'lydgate' at the top of 148r.

origin.origDate: Written partly or entirely after c. 1449 as 'An holy meditation to Our Lord Christ Jesus hanging on the cross' refers to John Lydgate (c. 1370-1449/50?) as 'late a monke of the house of Seynt Edmundus of Bery on whose sowle God have mercy' (f. 194r); and before 1454 as Richard Fox refers to the manuscript in his will dated 12 August 1454.
origin.origPlace: England, perhaps partly or entirely written at St Albans, Benedictine abbey of St Albans St. Albans Abbey.
origin.p: Richard Fox, who copied the fragmentary table of contents on f. 1r and the Middle English verse on ff. 194r-214v and rubricated the entire manuscript, was the proctor or steward of St Albans Abbey between c. 1435 and 1454.

provenance.p: The manuscript's first owner was Richard Fox (d. 1454)Fox, Richard (d. 1454), steward of the Benedictine abbey of St AlbansSt. Albans Abbey as is indicated by his will of 12 August 1454 in which he bequeaths the manuscript (identified by its opening text: 'Domine ne in furore') to his son John.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.1.6, ff. 246-247

msItem.title: Music for three polyphonic liturgical compositions
msItem.note: Musical settings for 'Deo gracias' (f. 246r), 'Paradisi porta per euam' and 'Sancta maria uirgo intercede' (f. 246v), and the Magnificat (ff. 247r-247v, imperfect (missing the last four lines), written in the 2nd half of 14th century.

handNote.p: The fragmentary music leaves are written in Northern Textualis.

decoNote.p: One-line plain capitals in red ink

provenance.p: 'Richard'Richard: his name inscribed in a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand on f. 246; the hand does not seem to match that of Richard Fox (d. 1454).

change.persName: Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
